@madebypatch @DeputyGrocott @chrisdysonHT @MrEFinch @PaulGarvey4 Signage by the way could be a class led activity. “If you were in a school in another country” - what signs ad picture symbols would help you understand what might be found in a room/ office/ drawer/ cupboard. Set up “language detective” discussions.

@madebypatch @DeputyGrocott @chrisdysonHT @MrEFinch @PaulGarvey4 Have a look at this site too as it will inspire you to see the multilingual opportunities all your learners will be able to explore once your new arrivals have settled in your school. https://t.co/H4wNMRN8X5

@madebypatch @DeputyGrocott @chrisdysonHT @MrEFinch @PaulGarvey4 Signage around school in both languages and greetings on class doors in Ukrainian. I work with schools where it is sometimes 98% EAL and signs just make things accessible and target language greetings make classrooms friendly places.

@madebypatch @DeputyGrocott @chrisdysonHT @MrEFinch @PaulGarvey4 Get hold of a bilingual dictionary in Ukrainian and English and set up games where your Ukrainian child can look up a picture and word in Ukrainian and a buddy child can find and read the word in English. Make it a class game. Just found this on Amazon https://t.co/20F9PvhzVj

@StefPianigiani @JoeBarnesMoran1 @gianfrancocont9 @simograv @valleseco Find this interesting. In every classroom there will be a range of ability,aptitude and interest in the subject area.I don’t think I’ve ever taught a class where every child or teenager has been just what I might have expected to receive.

@StefPianigiani @JoeBarnesMoran1 @gianfrancocont9 @simograv @valleseco Primary languages are taught well by many primary schools. Where there are issues then providing adequate training and support would help to ameliorate this. Money is often the issue.Big question to address is exactly what learning continuum we are trying to achieve and why?

Yes. In doing so don’t we first need to look beyond “learning a language”? We need to consider primary classrooms demographic,removing obstacles some colleagues have due to own language learning experience,learning from  pedagogical approaches in primary teaching….. https://t.co/DYOfHnSz6z

@JoeBarnesMoran1 @gianfrancocont9 @simograv @StefPianigiani @valleseco Yes. In doing so don’t we first need to look beyond “learning a language”.We need to consider demographic of primary classrooms, obstacles some colleagues have due to own language learning experience,learning from  pedagogical approaches in primary teaching.

@gianfrancocont9 @simograv @StefPianigiani Good to hear.Primary teaching and learning has much to offer when developing effective language learners/self efficacy. Well done to your team for addressing this and joining us as we build primary language learning bridge into secondary. @JoeBarnesMoran1 @valleseco

@valleseco @JoeBarnesMoran1 @sarahda60140245 @gianfrancocont9 The “primary voice” is so important. Should we impose secondary approaches ?Primary schools consider all chren /all types of learners. Whatever language skills we address then to me it makes sense to explore “primary” approaches to enhance understanding and benefit all learners.

@valleseco Have taught and observed learners who have high oracy skills and limited literacy skills. Always challenges me as do we negate/ dismiss a huge group of developing communicators in L2 because of lesser strength in a motor skill or putting pen to paper? Going to ponder this one ..

@valleseco Perhaps what we’ve been discussing over last day or so though begs question “is it a definitive assessment tool”?  What are we assessing? Ability to write freely? Ability to recall? Ability to memorise text? Ability to manipulate structure /adapt content in contexts? Interesting

@valleseco Writing probably goes much deeper than that too. Think also as language teachers we can ignore or underrate (not necessarily intentionally) chren who actually are developing linguists by looking sometimes for those who can best put language on paper too.

@valleseco Very important in my opinion that we understand that scribing and writing are different. Plus very important to see early language learners in@tbd same light as emergent writers in KS1 literacy. I try to explain my thoughts by saying that “writing is taking a thought for a walk”.
